notesStmt.note: Upper corners of front and back covers are damaged; front cover is beginning to separate from the spine
Leaf from an unrelated Book of Hours tipped onto the recto of front endleaf, possibly by Lewis; contains the beginning of the prayer "Obsecro te" with rubric "Or[ati]o beate virginis Marie"
De Ricci, Seymour, with the assistance of W. J. Wilson, Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada, vol. 2 (New York,: H. W. Wilson, 1935-40), p. 2036, no. 67.

Free Library of Philadelphia, A Descriptive Catalogue of the John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts in the Free Library of Philadelphia, compiled by Edwin Wolf, 2nd, with an introduction by Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach (Philadelphia: The Free Library, 1937), p. 113-114, no. 104.
TELMA-Luxury Bound: A corpus of manuscripts illustrated in the Netherlands (1400-1550)

msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This Book of Hours of the Use of Rome was most likely made in the Flemish town of Hainaut, as the calendar includes feast days for saints particular to Hainaut, including Waudru, a saint from the town and for whom the monastery in Hainaut was dedicated, her sister Saint Aldegund, and her husband Saint Vincent. The book consists of a calendar; the Hours of the Virgin with a special section of Hours for Advent; Penitential Psalms, Litany, and Prayers (illustrated with a miniature of Christ in Judgment, fol. 70r); and the Office of the Dead. It then continues with a more unusual set of texts: the Commendation of Souls (illustrated with an angel fighting a devil for a dead man's soul, fol. 113r); the Hours of the Passion with an historiated initial for each individual Hour; the Hours of the Trinity; the Hours of the Sacrament of the Altar; the Hours of the Holy Spirit; the Hours of the Conception of the Virgin; the Missus est Gabriel angelus Prayer to the Virgin; The fifteen O's of Saint Bridget (with a historiated initial of the Mass of Saint Gregory, fol. 183r); Prayers for Communion and to the Virgin; prayers to individual saints including Waudru (fol. 192r), Vincent (fol. 197v), and Saint Gregory (fol. 198r, with a second historiated initial of the Mass of Saint Gregory); prayers for the sick; and prayers to the deceased, to the sacrament, to our Lord, and to Saints Cosmas and Damien.

supportDesc.extent: ii+208+ii; 209 x 145 mm bound to 215 x 157 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto

p.catchwords: Horizontal catchwords, lower right verso, mostly cropped, visible in first two or three folios of each gathering

layoutDesc.layout: One column of nineteen lines, ruled in lead; prickings visible on some pages; one leaf with one column of fifteen lines, ruled in red; text continues on reverse; written area: 125 x 85 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: Five full-page miniatures with full borders, one half-page miniature; twenty-three historiated initials; red, blue, and gold decorated initials throughout; one inserted leaf with illuminated initial and inhabited border
Inside front coverBookplate, Reverend John Wright
42vHistoriated initial D, Annunciation to the Shepherds
46rHistoriated initial D, Adoration of the Magi
49rHistoriated initial D, Presentation in the Temple
57rHistoriated initial C, Massacre of the Innocents
60vLarge rubricated S, Large lowercase rubricated D
113rLarge miniature, Angel and devil fighting over a dead man's soul
119rHistoriated initial D, Agony in the Garden
146vHistoriated initial D, Angels with a Monstrance
167rSmall miniature, Mary with the Christ Child in her womb between David and another prophet
183rHistoriated initial O, Mass of Saint Gregory
192rSuffrages for Saints Waudru, John the Evangelist, Roch, Adrian, Anthony, Sebastian, and the Five Martyrs, followed by the Eight verses of Saint Bernard, and a prayer to Saint Joseph
197vHistoriated initial B, Saint Vincent of Hainaut
198rHistoriated initial O, Mass of Saint Gregory

binding.p: Eighteenth-century French morocco; gilt back and edges; marble paper pastedowns and flyleaves; stamped on spine in gold: "LIVRE D'EGLISES"

origin.p: Localized by Patricia Stoop to Mons, in the province of Hainault; circa 1470-1480

history.provenance: T. Royer (18th century); Rev. John Wright; John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936; Bookplates of the Rev. John Wright (inside front cover) and John Frederick Lewis (recto of front flyleaf); Entries from printed catalogues in inside front cover and recto of back flyleaf; "Manuscrit Heurs de Notre Dame" written in ink on verso of front flyleaf; "MSS: q to i. s. e" written in ink in the same hand on recto of first end leaf; Signature of T. Royer with his motto "Constanter" in ink in upper corner of recto of first end sheet
